title: Pastrnak scores twice, hits 400-goal milestone as Bruins beat Maple Leafs
author: The Associated Press
bullets: David Pastrnak scored twice, including his 400th career goal, in the Bruins' 5-3 win over the Maple Leafs.
Bruins' Jeremy Swayman made 30 saves; Pavel Zacha, Hampus Lindholm, and Alex Steeves also scored for Boston.
Maple Leafs' Auston Matthews left with a lower-body injury; Toronto has lost three consecutive games.

title: Jeff Passan maps out ‘perfect’ offseason move for the Red Sox
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox are targeting another top pitcher despite Garrett Crochet's success, aiming to strengthen their starting rotation.
Boston is reportedly revisiting a trade for Minnesota's Joe Ryan, who had a 3.42 ERA and 194 strikeouts in 2025.
Acquiring Ryan would require a package of prospects or players, as he is under team control until after the 2027 season.

title: Patriots players got a surprise blue-collared gift from Mike Vrabel
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Mike Vrabel gifted blue-collared shirts to New England Patriots players, inspired by his previous role with the Browns.
The shirt distribution mirrors past team morale boosters, similar to Joe Judge's 2023 motivational sweatshirts.
The Patriots are on a seven-game win streak, preparing for a prime time game against the New York Jets.

title: ‘Ride and Walk for Your Life’ pedals toward safer streets, will push for reform
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Ride and Walk for Your Life events in Boston include a memorial ride, walk, and rally for road safety reform.
Organizers advocate for Massachusetts legislation on camera enforcement and increased truck safety to reduce traffic fatalities.
Eric Olson, who lost his daughter, emphasizes coalition efforts to inspire progress in combating traffic violence.

title: Tips for getting stubborn bird droppings off of an SUV
author: John Paul
bullets: John Paul recommends using warm water and dish detergent to remove bird droppings from a Jeep Grand Cherokee.
Baking soda and water or a handheld steamer can be effective for breaking down stubborn bird droppings.
Consult a car detailer as a last resort if home remedies fail to remove the droppings.

title: Patriots have a new secret weapon on offense in 335-pound defensive tackle
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots utilize 335-pound defensive tackle Khyiris Tonga as a versatile player on both offense and defense.
Tonga's switch to fullback aids in key plays, including a 69-yard touchdown in a win over the Buccaneers.
Coach Mike Vrabel highlights Tonga's impact as a multi-phase player, contributing on defense, offense, and special teams.

title: What Joe Thornton said about the Bruins during his Hall of Fame induction speech
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Joe Thornton began his NHL career with the Boston Bruins, playing eight seasons and scoring 454 points in 532 games.
During his Hall of Fame speech, Thornton praised Bruins alumni like Johnny Bucyk and Wayne Cashman for their mentorship.
Thornton thanked the people of Boston and expressed gratitude for his early experiences with the Bruins during his NHL career.

title: Several key Patriots players still limited in latest injury report
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Key Patriots players including Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson remain limited in Tuesday's injury report.
Tight end Austin Hooper and defensive lineman Joshua Farmer did not practice due to concussion and ankle injuries.
Multiple players who were injured Sunday, such as Christian Barmore and Marcus Jones, participated fully in practice.

title: Man, ‘significant’ number of birds and snakes killed in Methuen house fire, department says
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: A house fire in Methuen early Tuesday resulted in the deaths of an adult man and numerous birds and snakes.
Firefighters responded at 2:20 a.m. to heavy fire and smoke at 38 Atkinson St., Methuen, overcoming entry obstacles due to clutter.
The cause of the Methuen house fire, which caused catastrophic damage, is under investigation by multiple local and state agencies.

title: What readers say Boston Mayor Michelle Wu should prioritize in her next term
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Readers prioritize housing affordability and public safety for Mayor Michelle Wu's second term, capturing 49% of responses in a poll.
Nearly 80 respondents urge Wu to tackle Boston's high cost of living with lasting solutions like changing zoning laws.
Concerns over public safety include crime, homelessness, and drug issues, with residents seeking more effective interventions.
